text: hello my name is Alasan a software
engineer here at AWS In this video I'm
going to show you how to work with
Arctic Arctic can be used to validate
any type of UI test without requiring
special application site support To
demonstrate this flexibility I'll walk
you through an interactive greet test
[Music]
example First let's clone Arctic from
GitHub You can also download Arctic Jar
directly from GitHub if you prefer
Arctic needs at least JDK1 to
run gradu command to create
jar I'm going to create a demo folder
This will be our working environment for
testing
I have a simple bash script
here which starts an arctic session run
set password test finishes the arctic
session and reports the
result Let's copy the arctic jar to our
demo folder
Now we are going to set up recording and
player
properties I'll set up the player
properties file
first The only setting I'm going to
change is RMI which I'm setting to local
only Depending on your setup you might
want to use true or false
instead Now I'll create the recording
properties This tells Arctic where to
save recordings and what format to use
screenshots I'll change DMI setting to
local only here as well
Now we are ready to start
testing It's a good idea to position
your terminal so it doesn't overlap with
the
workbench I recommend using a second
terminal window for recording and
playing test because you can monitor
Arctic and test logs better
I'm launching the Arctic Workbench in
recording
mode Now I'm running the test script in
the other
terminal This is an interactive GTH test
so I already have GTH downloaded and set
up Do not move the test window but
adjust Arctic workbench accordingly And
make sure to cover the whole test window
Use the shade window to hide fields that
you do not want to
record Now I'll start recording by
pressing control shift
C You can see the recording confirmation
in the terminal I'm manually running the
test as instructed When I reach
important points in the test I press
control shift X to capture
screenshots When you are done with
testing click on pass When the test runs
successfully it sends a signal and
recording
stops Now let's see how playback
works I'll run Arctic in player mode and
then launch the test
At this point I'm not touching my mouse
or keyboard Arctic handles all
interactions and compares new
screenshots with the recorded
ones If everything matches up the test
passes which returns a confirm message
If there are differences Arctic will
flag them as failures
and it returned confirmed This test
passed and that's it Arctic is powerful
This approach ensures your UI renders
consistently across the different
environments and catches visual
regressions before they reach users
